Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2009 08:34PM HelenNC wrote: I know it's overwhelming, but the fact that you found this board will help ease your anxiety alot. First, I asked my onc the same question about some not losing their hair with chemo. She said they had all tried another type chemo where patients did not lose it & then when the follow was done, their cure rate was not as high as it is for this type. So we'll lose our hair for sure. I start my first chemo treatment on Tuesday. As with any surgery you have, it's the anesthsia (spelling??) that takes long to get out of your system. It the reason you feel sluggish & sleepy. I think it's best to save your questions for your onc. I did. I also had a meeting with the chemo team, where I got most of my questions answered. Good Luck!
Posts.Title: So many questions...and scared. cherneski cherneski

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2009 03:17PM HelenNC wrote: My first chemo was today. I have to say it went quite well. No problem with putting in the needle. Didn't feel anything. Had a pleasant experience all around. I got: Aloxi, Adavan, Decadron,  Flush, then Cytaxon, then Taxiteer. I have to go back tomorrow for the Neulesta shot.So all in all, it was good. No side effects as yet

Posts.Content: May 21, 2009 06:24AM - edited May 21, 2009 07:56AM by HelenNC I am checking in after my chemo on Tuesday & Neulasta shot on Wed. I am in utter disbelief right now. I don't want to seem ungrateful, but how can I not be feeling the SE's? My onc told me to switch to tylenol for the bone pain & apparently it's working. Anyone else ever have a good week after chemo?

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2009 05:52PM HelenNC wrote: I had my surgery today for the Power Port implant. Had two other surgeries & they were a breeze compared to the pain I'm feeling with this port. I know my bs didn't give me the same meds as for the other two surgeries, but I wasn't expecting this! We both thought it would be the easiest one!. It's not really bad, don't get me wrong. But I had plans for tonight & I am sick enough not to go! Bummer. I'm achy all over & the port area hurts. I am taking pain meds, tho. Question: I didn't know til I got home I actually have two bandages. One for the port & another one down further. I don't remember discussing this w/my bs.

Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: May 9, 2010 03:07AM HelenNC wrote: About Wigs: I received 3 free wigs when I lost my hair. One was from the American Caner Society. Just went to their local office & picked one out. Another was from Susan G. Komen. I just emailed them & asked if they provided free wigs & she said to choose a wig salon & just email her the phone number. She called them & gave them a dollar amount & I got to go choose any one I wanted. Third one was from Crickett's Answer to Cancer orgaization. Same thing. Got it from a wig salon. So please don't "settle" for an ugly wig! Call or email! There is help available to us!

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2009 09:13PM HelenNC wrote: I don't have insurance. But am enrolled in a federal program funded by medicaid. So it will run out in a year & I have to pay for my meds then. Soooo, I did a bunch of research & am getting 4 wigs for free. The American Cancer Society gives wigs, turbans & head coverings for free. Call for your local chapter. Susan G. Koman also supplies a free wig. They said to give them my closet wig salon & they called them, gave them a dollar amount & I came home with a beautiful wig.  Another foundation, crickettsanswerforcancer.org is a wonderful organization started by a mother who lost her grown daughter to BC. She has offered my 3 websites to visit to choose a wig. I choose Paula Young Wigs. They have a special right now...buy one get one free on certain wigs. So I am getting 2 free wigs for the price of one....for free!  Also franceluxe.com will donate a beautiful headcovering for cancer patients. They sent mine & it's beautiful. And heavenlyhats.com
